Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Awards: Recursive Human - Environmental Interaction In An Estuary Setting

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
James Daniels, a graduate student at the University of California San Diego, will examine human adaptations to environmental pressures and the subsequent environmental responses to those adaptations. This co-evolutionary relationship can be investigated via study of the archaeological record in conjunction with study of natural sediment and soil profiles that record changes in past environments. The combined study of human adaptation and human impacts on the environment can provide insight into how environments respond to human activities and whether those responses are beneficial or detrimental to humans. Studying these processes may also provide insight into current and future human impacts and the kinds of human adaptation that produce the most favorable outcomes for both the environment and future generations of humans.

The project focuses on the shift to settled village life on tropical coasts of the New World. Mr. Daniels will investigate the recursive relationship between humans and their environment in this setting by focusing on the archaeological and sedimentary records that accumulated between approximately 5000 and 3000 years ago on the Pacific coast of southern Chiapas, Mexico. This wetland environment lies behind wide barrier beaches and consists of mangrove forests and lagoons within which there is a rich archaeological record of the Archaic and Early Formative periods. The project will unravel how Archaic and Early Formative occupants' manipulation of the environment through land clearance, planting, and other activities affected the stability of the estuary-lagoon system and may have created conditions conducive for the emergence of settled village life. The main hypothesis that will be explored is that increased inland land clearance during the Archaic and initial Early Formative periods contributed to the expansion of the mangrove estuary, thus creating an opportunity for Early Formative people to exploit a new abundance of wetland resources and ultimately to develop more sedentary subsistence strategies. The investigation will combine excavations on small mounds within the mangroves with examination of the history of barrier-beach formation downstream from the mounds. A precise chronology of changes in the two settings will facilitate reconstruction of what the environment was like when it was first colonized by people and how the environment responded to initial and subsequent human impacts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
James T. Daniels, Jr., supported by a National Science Foundation Dissertation Improvement Grant, conducted archaeological fieldwork in the mangrove estuary of southern Chiapas, Mexico to study Early Formative Period village life as adaptation to changing coastal landscapes. Daniels?s dissertation work is a continuation of the Proyecto Arqueologico Costa del Soconusco (PACS) started by Hector Neff in 2011. Daniels conducted archaeological excavations at two Early Formative Period sites, El Casta?o (RS-19) and Cerro del Tigre (RS-31), which were identified in the PACS 2011 LiDAR data. In 2017, Daniels began excavations at the two sites reaching depths of up to nine meters. Radiocarbon dates recovered from the excavations at RS-19 and RS-31 indicate that the sites were predominately occupied between 1600 and 1400 BC. The artifact assemblage includes ceramics that correspond to the Locona and Oc?s ceramic phases with some possible Barra phase ceramics from contexts below the current water table. Several hardened round pit features were encountered in the excavations at RS-19, some of which may possibly be remnants of salt production (Figure 2). The height of the mounds and the relatively short time in which they formed indicate they were intentionally built up rather than developing in a tell-like fashion over multiple generations. The stratigraphy, especially at RS-19, indicates that Early Formative inhabitants were constantly altering the surface of the site by excavating pits, laying down sediments collected from around the mound, burning clay surfaces, and quite possibly, using hydraulic concrete for various construction purposes.

While excavations at the mound sites in the mangrove estuary provided important data on the activities and subsistence strategies of Initial Early Formative inhabitants of the region, Daniels?s work also questions how Early Formative people came to settle in the mangrove estuary. Locations on the barrier beach bordering the mangrove estuary were cored in order to extract shell from sediments below the surface that were formerly in open ocean in order to date the formation of the barrier beach. Shell species common to shallow open ocean habitats were recovered from depths between 8 and 10 meters below the current beach surface in three different locations. Calibrated radiocarbon dates from these shell samples ranged from 753 cal BC to cal AD 324. The dates were used to estimate rates of progradation of the beach and the age of the initial formation of the barrier beach. Given the distance between core sample locations, the calibrated radiocarbon dates from the shell recovered, and visible relic beach edges in the LiDAR imagery, the beach is estimated to have begun forming around 2000 BC, just prior to the onset of the Early Formative Period. Daniels extracted two sediment cores from within the mangrove estuary for geomorphological and pollen analysis (results currently pending). The estimated date of the formation of the barrier beach coincides closely with the basal fine sediment dates from RS-7 Core 5, which lies in what would have been open lagoon or wetlands shortly after initial formation of the barrier beach.

Previous sediment coring by Neff et al. (2006; 2018) in this region have revealed disturbance indicators, charcoal spikes, and domesticates, including maize, in the sedimentary record from between 3550 and 2050 cal BC. This evidence suggests that increased inland burning led to increased inland erosion and sediment loads delivered to the coast during the Late Archaic period, which accelerated formation of the barrier beach and thus the expansion of the mangrove estuary. The changes in the coastal environment increased the returns from the harvesting of wetland resources, which is why we see an explosion of human occupation in the mangrove estuary after the initial formation of the barrier beach.

The implications of this project go beyond just advancing our understanding of archaeology and Early Formative human adaptations in Mesoamerica. The results demonstrate how coastal environments have been subject to human impacts throughout the Holocene, and what we see today is a profoundly human engineered landscape. Ironically, while the extensive mangrove stands of the Pacific coast are partly built by human ecosystem engineering, we are now rapidly destroying those human-made landscapes through tourist development, shrimp farming and pollution. This work may provide some insight into how modern-day activities and modifications of our environment may have affects on sensitive coastal environments. By examining how prehistoric humans altered the environment and the ensuing ecological feedback from those modifications may provide valuable data to apply to present day and future ecological models. 

The results of this project will be the focus of Daniels?s doctoral dissertation which will be completed in 2020. Several conference presentations and publications are in the works to disseminate the results of this project.
